NOTICE

The partnership known as McIntosh & Germond has been dissolved, and Mr.
James Germond who will settle all
claims presented to him against the
partnership. Notice is hereby given.

McINTOSH & GERMOND.

The Secretary of the Local Agricultur-
al Society has been authorized to require
a deposit of land rent not less than five
dollars per acre to be paid to the
Municipality of the town of Prince Albert for
the use of the Agricultural Society.
Applications for the above notice should be sent in
to the Office of the Secretary as soon as
possible, and a receipt will be issued therefor.
The Secretary will be pleased to hear from
any interested parties.

JOHN H. ROWELL,
Sec.-Treasurer L. A. S.

FOR SALE OR RENT
THE LELAND HOUSE
PRINCE ALBERT

Gentlemen, ladies and others,
I have decided to put up the hotel business for
sale. The house is in good repair and will
rent without further expense.
The house is now doing a large business
in connection with the hotel, and would suit
a gentleman who wishes to build up a large
business in a short time. This is the only
house in town which can be let to couples.

Apply to
D. POLLOCK, Prop.
Corner Ring and Silver streets.

of hay, oats and other farm supplies.

Terms—Cash on delivery.

Tickets $10, POLLOCK, Proprietor.

L.R. ST. LOUIS,

EXCELSIOR LAUNDRY.

Given & Starforth

Just before the last mail party, it was announced
that Mr. J. D. Mitchell, who was engaged to
look after the interests of the town, had
been killed by a bullet fired by a member
of the police force. Mr. Mitchell, while
engaging in a fight with another man,
received a bullet wound in the head.

At a meeting of our school trustees on
Monday last it was decided to make ex-
tensive arrangements for the coming
winter, so that the children may be
kept in school during the winter months.

Mr. Dowling, of Fish Creek, has just
returned from London, Ont., where he
was recently married.

Weather delightful. No snow. Roads
in good condition.

One of the prominent features of the
half day Friday evening was the elegant
supper provided by Mrs. Pollock, of the
Leland House. The supper was attended
by a large number of guests, who appeared
to be the best of the kind ever laid out in
the town. Many and profuse
were the congratulations, Mrs. Pollock
received.

A literary and improvement society has
been formed in connection with the
Church, consisting of members of
St. Paul's Young People's Association.

The officers elected are as follows—

President, Dr. Jacobus van der Kooi.
Vice-President, T. N. Campbell.
Secretary, John H. Rowell.
Treasurer, W. H. Newland.
Committee, Mrs. Knowles, Mrs. N. A. Stud, Mrs. Langton,
Mrs. McGregor and Mrs. Porter.

An entertain-
ment will be held every fortnight.

Edmund Kerr, Chesterbury, Ont., says:
"I am truthfully saying my name Nels is
being used by a certain party, and I fail to
understand why they should take another
better known name. If I complete my
story, I cannot expect me to be able to
make you see how my case was a very
bad one."

THE LELAND HOUSE

Beds—At Prince Albert, on the 8th inst., the wife of Basil U. Bain, M.D., of a son.

THE LELAND HOUSE BALL

The proprietors of the Leland House will hold a ball on Friday evening, December 14th, '88.
Friday evening, Dec. 14th, '88.
Good music piano and violin will be
played throughout the evening.
A first-class supper will also be pro-
vided.
All friends of the house and the gen-
eral public are invited to attend.
Tickets $10, POLLOCK, Proprietor.

COMUNICATIONS

BERGO ANSWERS.—
To the Editor of the Times.

Sir,—Can you inform me who is clerk
of the Municipality of the Town of Prince
Albert? Would like his address so that
I may apply to him about the time of
my appointment to assist them at
times for the convenience of the public,
and so on what days, etc.

I am also interested to know whether
for next year has been posted up in
the clock's office as required by sec. 160 of
the Municipal Corporation Act.

Why not? Perhaps some of the
councillors will kindly oblige the rate
payers by answering the above question.

ENQUIER.

DUCK LAKE.

Our gristmill is now running full time.
A meeting of the stock owners was held
at Butte on Monday last and the question
of granting scrip to 1888, was discussed.
Mr. Dewar, Mr. Milne, Mr. Donald-
ald, M.P., and Mr. Thomson, M.P.,
for Prince Albert, but they could not agree.
The question was referred to the members,
but no agreement could be come to, so
what action should be taken.

Mr. Dewar, of Buttefield, has been
for some days away elastic buying
cattle.

Mr. Mitchell, while separating his
cattle, found several of them killed by
one of the Highland cows made a charge
at him, running a horn through a sleeve.

At a meeting of our school trustees on
Monday last it was decided to make ex-
tensive arrangements for the coming
winter, so that the children may be
kept in school during the winter months.

Mr. Dowling, of Fish Creek, has just
returned from London, Ont., where he
was recently married.

Weather delightful. No snow. Roads
in good condition.

One of the prominent features of the
half day Friday evening was the elegant
supper provided by Mrs. Pollock, of the
Leland House. The supper was attended
by a large number of guests, who appeared
to be the best of the kind ever laid out in
the town. Many and profuse
were the congratulations, Mrs. Pollock
received.

A literary and improvement society has
been formed in connection with the
Church, consisting of members of
St. Paul's Young People's Association.

The officers elected are as follows—

President, Dr. Jacobus van der Kooi.
Vice-President, T. N. Campbell.
Secretary, John H. Rowell.
Treasurer, W. H. Newland.
Committee, Mrs. Knowles, Mrs. N. A. Stud, Mrs. Langton,
Mrs. McGregor and Mrs. Porter.

An entertain-
ment will be held every fortnight.

Edmund Kerr, Chesterbury, Ont., says:
"I am truthfully saying my name Nels is
being used by a certain party, and I fail to
understand why they should take another
better known name. If I complete my
story, I cannot expect me to be able to
make you see how my case was a very
bad one."
We earnestly commend the proposal of associations and other factists as well as to our readers generally by the speech delivered in Sylvanaville by Mr. R. E. Feeney of Montreal. It is an able and excellent exposition of the feelings of Canadians with respect to annexation or commercial union, and a severe rebuke to a certain class of Canadian and American politicians and abolitionists by the "Liberals" there he boldly asserted his loyalty to his country and characterized with the most profound contempt... The "professors who claim his patriotism in the North or South as a "political privilege who would make him a change of card, and all these who would get their political crimes at starvation; endure him whose fingers are touched at the mouth and power by a shower of their existence." Let those who are disposed to sneer at loyalty to Canadian institutions be silent. Heir speech will mark him utterly useless and undermine the best power.

The interesting part of Prince Albert will be very soon called upon to select a mayor and council to look after their interests during the new year, and it is but natural to suppose that some at least of those who may sit in the council a body will offer themselves for election. Now that their term of office is drawing to a close it would be well for them to give an account of their stewardship before again asking for the confidence of the people. We hereby take up three prominent members of the town council into our columns by pledging their votes. The councils of 1883 may have been as good as any others we have had, but can we not evolve something better? If so we shall vote there ourselves. We do not wish to criticize the actions of any of the members at present but will do so when the proper time arrives. There is a possibility now that we shall be called upon to elect a municipal body to take up some military company and an such an event it would be well for the town to have its best men looking after the interests of the municipality.

We have received from Mr. John Lovell who celebrated Montreal publisher's first paper his "Château Park and Hudson Bay Company's In course of publication. The book will be published in 19 volumes and will give a complete history of each of the Provinces and the North West Territories, giving an accurate list of facts, statistics with regard to population, education, industries and manufacturers: there will also be issued a separate top of each Part which will be sold. It will be in publication during 1885 and will contribute the outside world to be aware of the wealth and importance of our Dominion. Mr. Lovell is a man eminently qualified for the task he has undertaken, and we have much pleasure in recommending his enterprise to the favorable consideration of our own readers. The work will cost $15 per volume, the contents may be had for from $250 to $50 per volume: the volumes treating of Manitoba and the North-West will cost $50 each. Read in your clubs and to others who want to read. That work is the publication of the volume, which will have relations for sale. We wish Mr. Lovell every success in his gigantic enterprise.

Mr. Plaxton voted against minor exactions required by law allowing the benefit fees for billiard licenses within the limits of the province. This Assembly offers very promising things over the morning of the session, "Legislature," General Court of Council—where they appear to be wasting a good deal of time over it and to me it was as it had been when such things had better been considered, and that the Ordinances will not be left in the moulded up state in which some of them hitherto have been.

On the liquor question Mr. Betts and Capt. Haye voted for high license, while the other members from the town voted against it. The result of the debate on the subject appeared to be that the Assembly will request the Dominion Government to take a vote of the provincial divisions for and against the traffic in spirituous liquors. So far as we understand it appeared will indicate now that all parties will submit to the results of public vote by districts, but not a vote of the Territorials as a whole.

ST. ANDREWS' DAY.

The 3rd November being the day appointed by Scripture in honor of its patron saint, was celebrated by a grand ball under the auspices of St. Andrew's Society. The ball took place Friday night at the fourth annual assembly of the society and was most successfully attended by a large number of guests. The trustees of the Nobel Academy very kindly placed the new academy building at their disposal for the occasion, and that, in a great measure, contributed to the success of the entertainments held in both hall and the concert-room. Great regret has been expressed that the hall has been deprived of the equipment afforded by the ball, there not being any other suitable hall in town fitted out to hold a public entertainment of the kind. As it was there was ample accommodation for the guests present, but owing to the absence of the hall room, very few were present; the hall room was very tastefully decorated and all arrangements were conducted to the greatest satisfaction.

A Dead Drop!

ANNUAL MEETING

Of the Lorne Agricultural Society.

The annual meeting of the Lorne Agricultural Society was held in the Council Chamber last Monday afternoon. The attendance was not so large as that last year, but there was plenty of room for improvement. It is very surprising that an institution like this, which is entirely devoted to farming interests and gives the farmers a chance to see what is being done at home and abroad, should be paid altogether on the same basis as most fairs. The farmers who attend these meetings are doing their best to improve their farms, and they should be encouraged to do so.

The secretary read the minutes of the last meeting of the directors which were approved of.

The report of the auditor was next called for and a verbal report was given.

As the prizes and other accounts for 1888 had not all been paid the treasurer could not give a full report. However, it was ordered that a full report be given at the next general meeting.

The next order of business was the election of officers for the coming year. The Rev. Dr. Jackson and W. H. Miller were appointed secretaries.

For president, Mr. James McKay, Col. Spratt, Capt. Wm. Miller were nominated and on the ballot being taken and counted Col. Spratt was found to have the most votes and he was elected president.

There were four nominations for vice-president and the choice fell on Mr. A. Spencer. For 2nd vice-president there were three nominations but Mr. E. Pritchard had the most votes.

The choice of Sec. Treasurer fell on the Rev. John H. Howard.

The new executive officers were:

President—Col. Spratt
Vice-President—Mr. Spencer
Treasurer—Rev. H. Howard
Secretary—Mr. McKay

Mr. Macdonald, M.P., was also made an honorary member.

The matter relating to the disposition of the prizes and the funds of the prize winners will be handled by the directors.

After a motion was passed tendering a vote of thanks to the retiring officers the meeting adjourned.

Mr. Macdonald, M.P., has notified the secretary that he will give a special prize for the best horse carried him and bacon fit for transportation.

CURLIANA.

The first game of curling and match of the season was played on the rink yesterday afternoon between Old Countrymen and the Curling Club. The game was presented by Mr. Macdonald, M.P., brother of our members, which resulted in a victory for the Old Countrymen by two points.

The weather was promising three years ago and had to be won three years in succession before obtaining the coveted cup.

The Curling Club had won several times and were almost sure of doing so again this year, but yesterday was a bad day for curling as the snow was very deep.

The following are the scores:

Old Countrymen—Canada—13
Baker—Glen—12
Stewart—Sutherland—11
McTaggart—MacKay—10
Campbell—Sutherland—9
Majority for Old Countrymen—13

THE GLOBE Christmas Number

A GREAT HOLIDAY PAPER

New Type, New Press, Fine Paper, Five Handsome Lithographed Plates, First-Class Illustrations, Original Matter and Superior Workmanship.

THE BEST XMAS PAPER EVER ISSUED IN CANADA.

THE LITERARY MATTER in the Christmas Globe will be entirely original and will contain stories from the ablest pens in Canada. The subjects treated will be wholly Canadian.

FIVE HANDSOME LITHOGRAPHED PLATES accompany the paper, the principal one being a scene from Vancouver Island, B.C., from a painting by Mr. L. Collingwood, the celebrated artist.

MECHANICALLY THE Xmas Globe will be in every way first-class and no expense will be spared in having it surpass anything of the kind hitherto published in this country.

AS THE DEMAND will be very great, we would advise immediate purchase to avoid disappointment. We will be obliged if subscribers will send in their orders at once, as the paper will be issued in limited numbers, and we cannot undertake to print second orders.

The price of the Xmas Globe is 10 CENTS PER COPY.

It is intended to make the edition ready the first week in December in order to allow plenty of time for mailing copies long distances so as to reach intended destinations before Christmas.

THE GLOBE PRINTING CO., TORONTO.
